div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: KHEDIVE'S NEW YACHT
div.p: THE MAHROUSSA'S ACHIEVEMENTS

Tha first reigning Prince to become pos sexsed of s turbine yacht is the Khediva, whore Mahrogaea ran very snccersinl steam trials on the Clyde lest Thorsday. Built in 5 by Samad Bros., she was originally » two funnilled paddle-steamer of aboot 11 knots speed. When bis Highness decided'to dispense with the ose of ber, be consulted Professor Biles, of Glsegow, aod:bis partner, Mr. William Gray, and on their advice abe was rearranged thronghoat and fitted with Parsons turbines, driving three screws.

Last Tharsday, with four-fifths of her boiler- power, she rap for six hoara at a men speed of 16} knots—half a knot in excess. of the goarantee. On a fall-power trial oyer measured distances her average speed was 17] knota, everything working satisfactorily. Among the interested obrervers of ber steaming was Sir Philip Watts, Director of Naval Constraction. The alterations on the Mabrovssa have been carried oot by Messrs. loglis, of Point- house, who sre the contractors for the King's pew torbine yacht Alexandria.

div.head: THE HELOUAN LINE.
div.p: The Delta Light Railways since taking over this line have already carried out a2 extensive. programme of works. The line to Tcurah bas been doubled and relaid with heavy eighty poond rails, At the present time the whole line ia in odurse of being ballasted, which will coosidersbly assaist in obviating the dost noisanoe, which is sach sn inconvenience to passengers making use of this line. The new firet-clase carriages are already in service, and s nomber of sgcond-class carriages ef a some- what similar type will arrive naxt month. New engices/ and now boilers for the existing expected to arriveio a few weeks' time. 'The oarrisges are of Belgian, and the locomotives of English make. The antomatio brakes for all trains bave been ordered and « perfect system of signalling will be installed. Daring the summer some im- provémenta have been made in ths stationr, and the terminos at Bab el-Look presenta a very spick and span appearance. Helouan is rapidly developing ass residen- tial suburb of Cairo, and owing to the high rents prevailing in the capital many English people are taking Villas in Helouan. i It is hoped that the Casino will be re-opened next season, and with a good orchestra and an elsborate programme of entertainments, con- certs and other fixtures, it shoald prove » great attraction.

The new time-table for the Helooan Railway hss jast been issaed by the Delta Light Railway Co. Ltd. for the winter season and provides for a very liberal servica between Bab el Louk and this health resort. Foorteen expresses will ron daily from the Cairo termi- nos and thirteen for Helouan, and there is also s good service of slow trairs The Delts Light Railway Co. is msking every effort to improve this somewhat unpopular 'line, for which new and comfortable carriages have been provided. The donbling of the line between Cairo and Tourah will remove the necessity of waiting for passing trains, so that great panctaality may be now expected.

div.head: A PORT SAID NEED.
div.p: THE LESSON OF THE MUTINY.
(Prom ovr Coarnespoxpet.)
Port Said, September 19.

Lhave freqaently drawn attention to the peed for a guardship to ve permanently stationed at Port Ssid, and the recent grave matiny is s atriking confirmation of the advisability of having « craiser at the northera month of the Canal. At tbe moment when the oatbreak occurred H.M.S. Venus was at Alexandria, snd 20 grave was the position of affairs that she had to harry over here yesterday to be in readiness for any eventualities. Had the matineers obtained the opper, baod mach looting wonld have taken place at Port Ssid before safficient troops could have been on the scene, and the Eyyptiao Goverament woald have been held responsible for any loss ot damags thereby occasioned. Oar position in Egypt acd the Mediterranean entails the Imperial responsibiliyy for policing the torri- torial waters of Bgypt, inclading the "Saez Cansl. Mach capital might have bren made by those hostile to the Oocopation if we bad been found onable to cops with such a sitaation that might easily have arisen had not the Ottoman troops kept the convicts at bay.

Thare is plonty of daily work for a guard- sbip at Port Said if ooly ofa formal and official cbaraoter. Parthermora there is « great deal of 'valaable Admiralty property thore, the control over which in the absence of a gnardsbip is vested in the person of the British Consul, who acts as Naval Agent. Sach daties as fall within the soope of that position are far better performed by s gaardship than by a Consul, and the absurdity of the present sitaation is evidenced by the fact that the Consnl has not even an official boat or boat's craw, although he is Naval Agent.

div.head: HEALTH OF THE SULTAN.
div.p: It is reported that Professor von Bergmann desires to perform an operation on bis Majesty, who is soffering trom stone. After the Saltan's firet attack in August,.the Torkish surgeon, Nareddin Pasha, performed an' operation, which appears, however, not to have proved sofficieatly effectual.

Private reports from Constantinople state that the Sultan is suffering from deap mental depresaion a3 a conseq ence of his illness, and that his ootward appearance hasmach changed, The deaths within the Isst fortnight uf two high fonetionaries at Yildie Kiosk have made a deep impression apo the monarch. Nisban Bffendi, who died suddenly of apoplexy, was the Soltan's translator and political director of foreign correspondence, and anjoyed his M.jesty's confidence, while the death of the Chief Master of Ceremonies, Ibrahim Pasha, soon followed.

div.head: TURKISH COURT MYSTERIES.
div.p: A sensation has been cacsed in Constanti- nople by the sudden death of the Saltan's private censor of forsige telegrams. He bad spent the day at Yildiz Kiosk, and was on bis wsy home by water to bis country house at the end of the Bosphorus, beyond Boyokdere, when, ss he was leaving the stair, he collapsed and expired in the arma of the man to 'whom he was giving ap bis t cket. By reason of his office, Nichan Efendi was brought into relations of close confidence with the Sultan, aod bad in conseqvence many and malignant enemies. It is recalled that other men, oo copying positions similarly delicate, expired onder conditions startlingly simi and there are whispers that the event is one of those which in Torkey most notte mentionand above the breath.

div.head: SINAI CONTROVERSY.
div.p: THE DIFFICULTIES REMOVED.

Roater's Constantinople agent reports tha instractions have been forwarded to the Otto man Comtmissioner for the demarcation o Bee frontier between the Sinai Peninsula anc Syria notifying bim that an arrangement ha: been arrived at between Great Britain and. the Porte, which is in conformity with the agree ment of May 14, 1906.
'This result was obtained after protractec negotiations, which were, however, condacted in a friendly spirit on both sides.

lt will be remembered that a deadlock occurred in the work of demarcation on thé question of the extent of devistion permissible on the basis of an spproximate straight line from El Ksfab, on the Mediterranean, to « point three miles west of Akabah, which con. stitates the agreement of May 14.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GBNBRAI TRUST.
div.p: Sir W. F. Haynes Smith, who praside: 'at the meeting of the Rgyptian Land anc General Trost, Limited, held in London or the afternoon of Friday Inst, raid that since Jane 30 investments which stood st £18,465 had been realised st a rmall profit, and the amount bad been applied in meeting the out atanding amoont due for the porchase o! lands, which account bad been redaced by £15,703. The capital of the compady had been invested in bnilding lands at Cairo, Alex: andria, and Kbartonm, and in each oase the land bad improved in valoe. They wore advised that it was undesirable at present tc realise the properties, bot they were taking ateps necessary for the realisation of them to the best advantage.

The Gordon estates in Alexandria were 1 very valuable property, and they had refosed an offer which would, Have yielded « profit o £30,000. It woald Have been pleassnt to give large dividend in the first year of the company's operations, but it seemed expedient that, having taken the risk of purchasing the property, sbarsholders should reap the fall benefit to be derived from its proper develop: ment. It was the only remaining building site in Alexandria, which was a place that was growing in importance, and for this rea- son it was rendered indepsndent of the ordinary flactoations of land in Bgypt They had also declined an offer for another property, which woold have yielded a profit of £7,000, bat after considering expert advice they would get larger profits by waiting. Pend- ing these negotiations, many matters bad remained in arenes bat the Board were dealiog with new business on favourable term: and there was no reason to doubt that t operations of the company could be made saccess.

The following is tha Direotors' report, which wax presented at the Meeting : - 'The Board, jo laying the scooants before the shareholders for the first fifteen months of the working of the company, desire to point 'out that the perind bas been occupied in select- ing investments {or the company, and bave to report that t! lands parcbased have appreciated in vale sins their acquisition. Lands bave been parchised at Cairo and at Alexandria and ller areas at Khartoum. Some of the smaller blocks at Kbartoam have been realised at a' profit which is sufficient, with interest, commission, &, to meet all the expenses of the period.

The most important investment is the por- chase of some 217,180 rqnare pics of the Ghorbal Batate at Alexandria. This large property is one of the last r ing boilding areas in the quadrilateral which forms A andria, and tbe land in the immediate vicinity bas recently risen very greatly in price. The Board are taking steps to develop this excep tional property and. to realize it for the bea advantage of the shareholders. '

The proposals which made to the company for 'amation, and the subsequent negotiations which formed tha subject of consideration at the recent Special Meeting bave vatorally delayed the activn of the Board in various directions ; bat the Board are now dealing with offre which appar to be favourable for extending the operations of the Company.
The Board have depnted one of their di- rectors, Mr. Maok, to take charge of the bariness of the company in Rgypt and to proored with the reslizstion of the lands which are ripe tor sales

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The faneral convoy of the late Princess Rokya Pazil left Inoba palace at foar o'clock yesterday afternoon escorted by mounted police and beaded by the Shiekh, ulemae and rokbeas from Al Athar. The chief mourners wore Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha, Said Halim Pasha, Ahmed Kamel Pasha, Aly Hoeidar Fadel, Ibrahim Pasha Halim, and Omar Pasha Toussoun.

The death of Ibrahim Pasha, Grand Marter of Ceremonies, and Dragoman of the Imperial Divan, is réported from London to bave made a profoand impression on the Saltan, as 6 w.8 one of his Majesty's, moat confidential and trastworthy servants. He had oooapied the post of Dragoman since 1899, which necessitated his presence at all interviews with Ambassadors and his inolosion in all direct negotiations with the Saltan. Ibrahim Pasha s oniversally liked and esteemed for his immense tact, which was frequently of great assistance in difficalt sitoations,

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
div.p: LIBERAL OPINION.

The Liberal and Ministerisl newspaper, the the ' Tribane," remarks as follows in regard to the latest White Book on the Denishawi affair. We have dealt with the subject in our leading article today :—
The effair is clcsed ; ithas been di-coased in Parliament without the full docomenta ; it has prédaced its moral effect in Bzypt, ard nothing which we can row say by way of com-

'ment can ir fl 1enca its inevitable conerqrences. I: will be,we are convinoed, an isolated incident, ' sod thongh Sir E!ward Grey defended the whole proceedings o1flinchingly in bis public stterances, be will not, we think, allow it to ba repeated. Ths trial bas impressed even sympathetic Prerch observers (like the writer of tha recent letter in the *"Temps") as a pnrely political »ffsir, and the veageaoce exactei is recognizsd by every ~andid man who knows the facts as excessive in conception sod barbarous in execution. Piecing 'ogether the story as it is told in evidence. we see no reason to sbate the criticism which we made originally. The Coort wes sn exceptional tribanal, appointed ad hoo, aod 83 tbe coonsel for the prorecation pat it, it "waa not boond by any law," or, rather, it "could apply any law." "It is s'guificant, toc, "tbat the prosecution opened with a eulogy of "the: British occupation, and so raised the political -iseue at once." Some fifty two natives were tried in a body, standing together with nombere badges roond their necks, ard even with this genezous assistance to identification, we thick that few Boglish lawyers would feel sstivfied that the officers wera really able to identify thess who astoally strock thom in the midst cf s covfased melee. Iudeed, they teldcm esred 'to asvert more than that they had seen this or tha other faco among the crowd, and in more than one instance their evidence was contradictory.

The provocation is clearly established. It coms that the family which took the lesd in the slirsy made their living from the village «dove-cota and the coanse! for the prozecation insisted on the fact that they had resented thécondact of'an Boglish pasty which shot their pigeons onder similar circumstances a year sgo.. 'Indeed, he declared that "the natives had hed the intention to marder from last'ycar, being ivfuriated at the abooting of tke 'pgeons." In thesa circomstdnces it is bardly surprising tbat the accidestal firing of thé barn and the wounding of four natives (inclading s,womav) by-sccidental shots from the officers' guos brcks dowa their self restraint. The medical cross examination is not given at length, bot in the nitive reports of the trial it came ont clearly that Captain Boll's death wea not sufficiently explaired by the blows he had received ; it was doe to violent exertior, combined, with shock and aggravated ty sun- stroke. No:Boglish jay in such circamstarces would hive broaght in a verdict of morder, and certainly no Boglieh Jadge would hsve sentenced s man who had. beaten trespassing sportamen, aftér they had, bowever acciden- "tally, fired bis barn and wounded his wife, to penal servitude for lifa. It is only recently that » welltby American who shot s poacher in Scotland under much less provocation was triompbantly acquitted by au Bdinturgh jury.
COMMAND OF THE SEA.

The snonymons writer i in the "Fortnightly," who adopts the nom de guerre of "Exoabitor," points out that the ficarcial resalt of the German naval policy is far more remarkab!e than. is generally understood, In the last three yesrs—19°4.1907-—British naval expenditore has teen reduced by seven millions. Germany, in 1897, speot on her fet £1,31,000; in 1904 the outlay bad arisen to £10,558,105, and onder the new amending-Act ths estimates will go op from year to year antil 1917, whan the outlsy will Smount to £16,137,000. There is no psraliel iu oy float for auch « rapid increase of expen- diture. The navy votes in 1917 will mark an inoresse of 273.6 per cent. over thor of 1997, ® period of only 20 years, If the ovtlay on "the Britich flaet were to keep pace with the relative growth'in German naval expenditure, the Britith Navy estimates in 1917 would amougt to over £60,(00,000—a preposterous figure. No one would seri ly suggest any such increment for the Britirh fleet. On'the other hand, it is absurd that advocates of naval economy in England should endeavour to ignore this movement on the other side of the North Sea, only three han fred miles trom our own th res, or that they abould biush aside prophecies as to the tatare, on the ssenmption that tho German aathrities pro ceed on our own haphazard lines, which render the tlaet the mark for the proving koife of 'every nowly-fledged Minister inter.t 01 8 popa Jor Budget,

Thero is one element of consolation, * Ex- cabitor" pointe ont, for Bngland:— "Germany, with her great and increasing oversea com- merce, wll not rivk' her commercia! interests by any war with "the greatest sea Power' un'oss rhe is nsanred of vic tory. It lies with _ the Britith peoyle, in no spirit of unfendli hes', but with tha same carefulness that Ger many evbibita in goarding her Pronch and Hassisn frontiers, to ree that the provision for the dofeoce- if Brit'sh interests ogainat all comers is adequate.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

The demands tor gold from America have 3) been Iarge, and twoand-a-half milljons have been withdrawn from the Bank mainly for that quarter. A rise in the Bank rate to 4% is the result, and the market is steady, with loans from day to day at 3 to4 per cent., and-dis. connt 3% for €0 days' billa, The position of the Bank ia better than Iast year at this period, althongh the reserve hes, fallen 2} per cont. The importince of not disturb'ng the London market onduly is well recognised. Sach distar- bances would revct opon countries with greater force, and would not avit either New York, Paris, or Borlio. We anderstand terms are being msde stringent for loans agsinst Ameri 1} can securities in order to bring home to the financial circles in New York that they mast come to their own ha'p in case. of any forther large demands, Its 4 percent. rate is the ole result of the usoal Antomn rqueezs it will not have avy bad effect ; in fact, it ism good thing for the lenders in the open market who are ready to take advantage of it. After all, with trade busy, {4 percent isa very healthy rate, and never stops legitimets basiness of any kind. With £1,700,030 on the way from the Uspe, and Exchange moving in oor favonr, no scarcity need be feared #0 long as America sc's prod- ently, sud webave no reason to donbt that Mr. Shaw quite appreciates the position. At present New York seems to have taken all want, at any rate for the present. The smount withdrawn for Egypt this week in the eame direction—in fact, as we write it is anderstood that three-q arters of a million | are being withdrawn. It is ramonred that the Back of France has cffsred to advance/ gold for this temporaty demand, Although they are wel sble to do this witbout fooling it, the report is not yetconfirmed. .
The Stock Markets.

The robbing of Peter to pay Paul—in other words, the oontinned heavy withdrawsls of gid for New York,~ has again been the pre- dominating it Hnence here. Egypt's gold de- mand hss also become » considerable factor in the sitgation. These heavy drains on oor stock st the Bank have natorally bad » de- pressing ¢ffect cpon the stock markets. Added to this, the operations connected with the rettlement bave been cnosvally heavy, so that, on the whole, the amount of new business transacted has beon slight. The osrry over bas been eflected withoat ary failores boing snnoonced, alihorgh there has been « certain amoont of anxiety in some quarters... The incresee in the Bank rate to 47, although it bad been expected, came as s considerable relief, and it is confilently-hoped that, new that the Amer demand has been to a large extent supplied, esrier money condi- tions, and with them, more active basiness on the Stock Excharge, may soon be the order of the d:y. ,Tha tone of markets was moch more cheerfal yesterday, w th the excep tion of the giltedged section, which was de- pressed by the shrinkage in the reserve, and next week we sbvuld be ab'e to report active dealings in al! markets.
Console.

First class securities have been in a state of acute depression, Consols having touched. 86 Romoors of gold axistance from France were responsible for a sharp aivarce on Wednesdey bot the farther American withdrawal of £400,000 yesterday, and the lack of confirma- tion of the reports of an arrangement between the Binks of England and France, cansed another re'apse. Coneols leave off to-night at
Foreign Bonds.

Romours of a probable early conversion and redemption of the Six per Cent. loans bave created an active demand for Japanese bonds. Toe Poors baveadvancad to 94 and the New Poors to 8-2 'The other series aro also higher, Rassisns are firming up, the Fours are now 72, and the script of the New Loan 11 discount.
Home Ralls,

'There is still little to report regarding this section, Yesterdsy there was some demand for the leading shares, bat the business dope was only small, Until the investing public decide to recognive the exce'lent proapedts of these shares, snd give them the attention they most certainly deserve, the market mast remain in the hopeless condition in which it bax becn for 80 long.

The traffis returns this waek are somewhat mixed. The- North Ba-tern -teport a gain of near'y £13.000,the aud Midland show» decrease | of £3,234, which, howaver, ia compared with a heavy increaso last year. The Metropolitan have | a decrearve cf £2,422. In the main the traflics were ignored by the market.
Americans.

For the greater pert (f tha week the Amori can market was the victim of pessimism regard. ing the money position, but with an easing of yesterday the aspect was totally changed, aubstantial hardening of prices took place Chicago-Milwaukee, which since oar last had lost 6 points, gainel 4 to 186, and Unions advanced 34 to 196}. New York Central and Louisville were re-peotively 3 and 2} higeor. 'foday thore bax been rome rosction on over: Light advice: fom New York, wher oonniderable profir taking took place yosterday. Prices venerally are weaker, Milwackees closo at '83 and Unions at 194) x.d, Canadian Pacifica sre {down on the week at 143}, hem

div.head: COTTON STATISTICIAN'S DEATH.
div.p: We regret to-learn of the death, throogh » street accident(at New Orleanr, of Mr. Heory Neill, the well ku representative of Messrs. Neill Pres bod. Mr. Naill, whose estimates of the n crop have for many yesrs been of world-wide interest, bad been established in the United States as cotton merchant for over fifty years, first as a partner io the firm of Neill Brothers, and for the past forty years as their New Orleans agent and correspondent, under the style of Henry Neil and Co. Mr: Henry Neill was knocked down bya tramear and killed.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: GAMBLING IN COTTON
div.p: Mr. Charles Stewart, of Liverpool, lectured on "The Cotton Market" to the mnombers of the British Assoistion of Managors of Textiie Works in. Manchester Inst week. Ho dealt mainly with American cotton, because, as ha said, the growing and consamption of American cotton directly rales the cotton markets of the world: Byyptian, Brazilian, Bast Indian, and other growths have very considerable efforts at times, bat the Ame- rican outpat rales. Mr. Stowart desoribed a '8 misoonosptio'- the ifea that the cotton in South America is planted by plantera owning thousands of sores of land, and owning hondreds of workpeople. Seventy-five per cent. of the American cotton crops was grown by negro farmers who did not prodace more than five or ten bales s year. The cotton bale was tbe negro farmer's cash, which figarative'y ho damped on the counter in retarn for food and olothes. In the stores the bales sccuma- lated, and they wera bartered until they reached the port of shipment, where the sorting was done. The factor sold it to the merchant, and eventually from the remo'e par's in the cotton be.c, at New Orleans or Galveston, the cotton was shipped. At this point "fatures" came into p'ay. If it wera not for the fatare- market ths importation done in Liverpool would be absolately impossib'e. As to ex- changes of cotton contracts, he stated that it was a fallacy that there was not cotton behind the "deal." [ta msn boaght a fatare contract he mast either sell a "fatare" or hy must take the ba'esand pay for them in ten days. Thore was always cotton bobind # contrast. He did not defend tha manipalator, who was loathed as mach in Liverpool as he was losthed in Manobester by the coosamer. 'Tho manipalator did not belong to the ootton market iteelf ; ha was only one of ths parasites on tha cotton market.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
